summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that laying an Ordinance by the Governor of a State before the State Legislature is mandatory under Article 213(2) of the Constitution. In our series of letters from African journalists, film-maker and columnist Sharmila Tagore looks at the role of the Governor of a State in the exercise of his legislative power. In our series of letters from prominent Indian lawyers, senior advocate Krishna Kumar Singh looks at the meaning of disapproval of an Ordinance by a Resolution as mentioned in Article 213(2)(a) of the Constitution where a positive act of approval of a Proclamation issued under Article 352(1) of the Constitution is necessary.

summary: The appellant has filed this appeal against judgment of the Bench of Madras High Court dated 223, by which judgment the High Court while reversing the judgment of trial court and First Appellate Court, has decreed the suit of plaintiff. This is a case of a temple executive officer, Arulmigu Bhaskaran, who has filed a suit against a private company, Chandran & Ors, for the possession and enjoyment of a suit property, which is in possession of the temple for a long time continuously. The Supreme Court of India, in a landmark case, held that the High Court in exercise of jurisdiction under Section 100 CPC has interfered with the concurrent findings of the facts, recorded by Courts below that the plaintiff has failed to proof his title and possession.

summary: This is an appeal against the High Court's decision of 15 January, 2017 to dismiss the respondents' appeal against the acquisition of their land. The appellant has filed an appeal in the Court of Appeal against the judgement of the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad dismissing his writ petition challenging the acquisition of his land under the Land Acquisition Act, 1991. In a landmark judgment, the Supreme Court has ruled that a landowner, whose lands were acquired under the Right to Fair Compensation and Transparency in Land Acquisition, Rehabilitation and Resettlement (RFRA) Act, 1999, can challenge the acquisition on the ground that it was not feasible to release the lands of the respondents and others from acquisition under Section 48(1) of the Act.

summary: A bench of the Supreme Court of India, headed by Justice Dipak Misra, has taken up an appeal against an order of the Allahabad High Court which had set aside a release order of the Uttar Pradesh Urban Buildings Authority, Moradabad, on the ground that the appellant was not the owner of the premises. The appellant was a student of B.Sc. and was of marriageable age and as the matter went before the appellate authority, the situation changed as the Court noticed that the appellant was married on 23.01.1996 and her husband was a member of Indian Revenue Service who was, at that time, posted at Delhi and subsequently in Mumbai. In Nidhi vs Ram Kripal Sharma, the Supreme Court has held that a landlord is entitled to the vacant possession of his rented premises in the event of his bona fide requirement for his own residential or professional requirements or for any person related to him.

summary: The Supreme Court has set aside an order of the Himachal Pradesh High Court which had withdrawn a writ petition under the Recovery of Dues (Recovery of Dues) Act, 1973. A loan of Rs.25,000/- was availed by the Respondent on 15.12.1988 for a truck industry and a hypothecation-deed executed in respect of property bearing Khata/Khatuni No.102/347, Khasra No.1014. The Supreme Court has held that where a plaintiff withdraws a suit without permission of the court, he is precluded from instituting any fresh suit in respect of the same subject-matter.

summary: The Uttarakhand High Court has set aside the order of dismissal of a bus driver who was found guilty of driving a vehicle without a ticket. The High Court of the state of Andhra Pradesh has set aside the award of the labour court of the state of Andhra Pradesh on the ground that non-supply of the inquiry report prior to the issuance of show cause notice vitiated the disciplinary proceedings. The Supreme Court of India has ruled that non-supply of report of the inquiry officer to the delinquent employee cannot automatically result in quashing or setting aside of the order or the order being declared null and void.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has set aside a lower court's order which had dismissed an appeal by a company against a tax evasion notice issued by the Income Tax Department in 2012. summary: The Supreme Court has issued notice to the State of Telangana on an appeal by Varala Bharath Kumar and another appellant against the order of the High Court of Judicature at Hyderabad suspending the criminal proceedings against them. The appellant no.1 has filed an application under Section 70(2) Cr.P.C. seeking to recall NBW issued against him and directed appellant no.2 to file an application under Section 205 Cr.P.C. In a landmark case, the Supreme Court has held that the High Court can exercise its extra ordinary jurisdiction to quash criminal proceedings against a husband who is accused of harassing his wife to satisfy unlawful demands of dowry.

summary: This appeal is being heard by the Sikri Bench of the Supreme Court of India in the matter of M/S Palam Gas Service vs Commissioner of Income Tax on 3 May, 2017. Section 40(aia) of the Income Tax Act, 1961 provides as follows: "Notwithstanding anything contained in this Act, no tax shall be payable on any sum paid by any person to any contractor or sub-contractor for any purpose other than the payment of freight expenses for the carriage of LPG cylinders. As per the rules of the Income Tax Department, it is the statutory obligation of a person, who is making payment to the sub-contractor, to deduct tax at source at the rates specified therein.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has upheld the decision of the Allahabad High Court that made it mandatory for those who had 50% marks in post graduation to be appointed as teacher in schools. The National Council for Teacher Education (NCTE) vide its notification dated 23rd August, 2010 laid down the B.Ed. The National Council for Teacher Education (NCTE) in its notification dated 23.8.2010 had said: “Candidates who are B.Ed. qualified in NCTE notification dated 23.8.2010 and subsequent State Government Order dated 29.4.2011 as violative of Article 14 of the Constitution of India.”

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that the Central Government may, by notification in the Central Gazette, direct that the duty of excise in excess of that payable on such goods, but for the said practice, shall not be required to be paid. The High Court of India has held that the Central Government has the power to issue a notification under Section 11C of the Cigarettes and Other Tobacco Products Act, 1988 (the Act) banning the use of power in the manufacturing of Rosin and Turpentine. The appellant was granted exemption from excise duty on the basis of exemption granted by the Central Excise and Service Tax Appellate Tribunal, Mumbai (for short ‘CESTAT’) in the case of lifting of water into the cooling tank of the aforesaid goods.
